CAN-commits.author: onura
CAN-commits.message:
fix: Arp spoofing poisons other devices although arg.spoof.targets is set to a single IP.
Although a target IP is set for arp spoofing, other devices get poisoned. When I analyze the traffic, I can see that bettercap-ng keeps broadcasting ARP replies.I mean target Mac is specified in ARP but not ethernet. This also cause a lot of GARP replies to be sent by colliding endpoint (probably gateway). This pr fixed the issue by sending unicast ARP replies as specified at RFC826.

CAN-commits.author: Karl
CAN-commits.message:
Fix crash when MUX index is not specified in DBC

Fix a crash when the MUX index is not specified inside the DBC file. In
this case, we previously would crash with the following error:

    IndexError: list index out of range

This would happen because the MUX decoding would fail and raise an error
when an invalid MUX index was passed, but the DecodeError would be
caught and then serialized into a string, leading to the IndexError
when the code later attempted to index into it.

This change propagates the error to the monitor subparser's update
function. Here, we handle the invalid MUX index the same way as if we
received an unexpected CAN message that wasn't specified in the DBC, and
discard the message.

CAN-commits.message:
plot: one legend per subplot (not per axis)

since commit ca60f98fb033d3ddaaf7135e890c24d0d28cdab9 it is possible to have different signals on different vertical axes in the same plot.
By default subplotlib creates a separate legend for each axis.
I think having only one legend per subplot looks better.
There was no explicit visible connection between legend and axis anyway.
For distinction which signal belongs to which axis ylabels are created automatically since commit 3be96b494ac6830fa762f232a6672cef977f9a54.

This broke all tests because legend is now called later and with arguments.
I have fixed the old tests by ignoring all calls to legend.
While I was at it I have implemented the functionality to easily add more attributes to the mock objects which can be ignored or not ignored depending on the arguments passed to the constructor.
I still need to implement new tests for the new functionality added in this commit.

CAN-commits.message:
Fix frame collisions between extended and standard frames

If an extended frame was having an ID that would be <= 0x7FF, then it would collide with the ID of a standard frame

This is fixed by setting the top bit i.e. OR'ing the frame by 0x80000000 similar to what is done in DBC files and in the Linux kernel

Fixes #654

CAN-commits.author: Maximilian Güntner
CAN-commits.message:
signal{encoder/decoder}: fix byte order & size calculation (#206)

* signal{encoder/decoder}: fix byte order & size calculation

The PDF that supposedly describes the DBC format got
the byte-order apparently wrong :)

The correct values are:
0 => big-endian, motorola
1 => little-endian, intel

Both encoder/decoder do bound checks before inserting the
bits into the raw signal. The bound checks need to take the
endianess into account because:

if the signal is little_endian / intel, start_bit describes
the LSB, so end_bit = start_bit + signal_size
if the signal is big_endian / motorola, start_bit describes
the MSB, so end_bit = start_bit - signal_size + 1

* Fix Big Endian handling for Signal Decoder

Signed-off-by: Remigiusz Kołłątaj <remigiusz.kollataj@gmail.com>

* Fix missing argument in a log line

Signed-off-by: Remigiusz Kołłątaj <remigiusz.kollataj@gmail.com>

* Typos fixed. Python script for generation of transition table simplified

Signed-off-by: Remigiusz Kołłątaj <remigiusz.kollataj@gmail.com>

* Fix CanSignalEncoder logic and tests

CAN-commits.author: Kevin O'Connor
CAN-commits.message:
can2040: Fix tx hang after error frame during tx

The code was not properly detecting a "tx conflict" condition on
transmits.  As a result, the code may not reattempt a failed
transmission until some other node on the canbus initiates a transmit.
If no other node attempts a transmit for an extended period of time it
could result in can2040 "locking up" for that extended duration.

The error was due to the PIO hardware reporting of the active
instruction address.  On an "irq wait" command it was reporting the
address of the next instruction.

Update the PIO tx state machine to loop on the "tx_conflict" address.
This allows the host software to correctly identify if the tx state
machine has observed a transmit bit conflict.

Signed-off-by: Kevin O'Connor <kevin@koconnor.net>

CAN-commits.author: Maximilian Güntner
CAN-commits.message:
Fix several issues with the dbc parser (#29)

* tests: add comfort.dbc file

this file has been copied 1:1 from
https://github.com/ANCIT/pythoncan-examples/blob/master/python-can-examples/resources/comfort.dbc

and is  licensed under the EPL 2.0

This dbc file seems to have been produced with a Vector tool
and features EV_ (environment variables) and BA_DEF with FLOAT
values. Both of which are missing in the peg parser grammar.

* peg parser: add FLOAT to ba_def_num

* peg parser: add ev tag

ev_ lines define environment variables

* peg parser: ba_sg can have phrase / string values

* dbc_grammar: allow escaped quotation marks \" in phrases

fixes problem described in https://github.com/GENIVI/CANdevStudio/issues/196#issuecomment-576567892

CAN-commits.author: Andrea Galbiati
CAN-commits.message:
Object oriented refactoring with unit tests (#2)

* Refactoring with object oriented approach

This commit contains several refactorings.
- Splitted DbcParserClass into Dbc, Parser and Packer
- line parsers are now classes
- Fixed comment and table values, now checking message ID.
- Added multiplexing support
- Added support for stream parsing
- Added comment support for nodes and messages

All original classes are unchanged (except a couple of fields that have been added).
The intent here is to get an idea about how it would look like.
I have been using Visual Studio Code from a Mac, so I could not compile. This commit should not be merged

* Added test project for future refactorings

Only basic tests have been added, more can be provided, especially on the pack/unpack part.
Two are failing because to me code does not meet expectations. If not, simply change tests accordingly.

* Added some more tests on new classes

* Added SignalLineParserTests

Added unit tests on this class. Also added an unused Regex version, just to see how it looks

* Added tests for Value Table line parser

* Create DbcBuilderTests.cs

* Marked class as obsolete

* Readme and demo are now using new classes

* Added missing .Name

While frames with an CAN-ID > 0x7FF always require the

with an ID <= 0x7FF.

From CAN bus side, the following CAN frames are both
valid, not equal from CAN ID side, and do not lead
to bus collisons (as they would do, if both were in
standard format):

     123 [8] 11 22 33 44 55 66 77 88
00000123 [5] 44 33 22 11 00

Introduced with 23e54b294d3e96a669fff16f2f5343373fb6010a

CAN-commits.author: Andre Hartmann
CAN-commits.message:
SocketCAN: Fix frame write error handling

Part I

If ConfigurationParameter::CanFdKey is not set,
the SocketCAN driver is not forced to CAN FD mode.
Therefore, writing CAN FD frames fails, even if the
bus (virtual or real) is CAN FD capable.

The existing error handling code already checked this,
but only if the CAN FD frame payload was longer than
eight data bytes.

Now the error message also appears when trying to write
CAN FD frames with payload size 0...8.

Part II

In line 348, QCanBusFrame::isValid() is called. This
function returns false if the payload size exceeds
the frame's maximum payload length. The function
SocketCanBackend::writeFrame then early returns
with false.

The maximum size error handling code is therefore
no longer reached and can be removed.

Change-Id: I9962a90fabd0678fe9040166b7c19946fbf6fd78
Reviewed-by: Denis Shienkov <denis.shienkov@gmail.com>
Reviewed-by: Alex Blasche <alexander.blasche@qt.io>
Reviewed-by: Rolf Eike Beer <eb@emlix.com>

CAN-commits.author: Andre Hartmann
CAN-commits.message:
VectorCAN: Fix receiving frames with extended ID

Beside the CAN ID, the bit XL_CAN_EXT_MSG_ID
is stored in event.tagData.msg.id. This bit
indicates, that the received frame has
extended frame format.

However, this bit must be masked before calling
QCanBusFrame::setFrameId(), otherwise the frame
is marked as invalid with the ID set to zero.

Most likely this was broken by commit
a54fd820916caed2fb13b1a38e57deb5d918f74f

CAN-commits.author: Alex Blasche
CAN-commits.message:
Fix RTU Master ignoring responses due to being in Send state

The fix for QTBUG-62299 limits the processing of serial responses
in RTU serial master to cases when the state machine is in receive mode
only. So far the Receive state was triggered by the sendTimer. However
modern kernels accept serial packages faster then the sendTimer can fire.

This patches addresses the problem by setting the Receive state even before
sendTimer fires. If the bytesWritten() callback detects that the entire
PDU/ADU was written it stops sendTimer and immediately progresses the
state machine to the Receive state.

Fixes: QTBUG-69188
Change-Id: I1657973ef99f1b3e4008e887029b30890d825d59
Reviewed-by: Karsten Heimrich <karsten.heimrich@qt.io>

CAN-commits.message:
CAN-Example: Fix two issues with the status timer

1. Fix a crash when device open fails

If opening of m_canDevice failed, m_canDevice is reset to
nullptr in line 154. Dereferencing that leads to a crash.

2. Avoid connecting multiple slots to status timer

Opening and closing multiple times lead to multiple
connections of the lambda slot, which triggered the
call to m_canDevice->busStatus() unnecessarily often.

The solution is to do the connection only once,
and stop the timer when m_canDevice becomes nullptr.
It is started again after a successful open.

Amends f83587a9978bd212d

CAN-commits.author: Andre Hartmann
CAN-commits.message:
CAN: Fix overreading QByteArray buffer

The old code did not take the size of the payload
QByteArray into account, so that for small payloads
read accesses outside the QByteArray data field
occurred.

While this should be no big problem in reality,
memory checkers like Address Sanitizer will report
such issues.

We now only copy the bytes the payload QByteArray
really provides. We can do this, as every derived
QCanBusDevice::writeFrame() method already does a
QCanBusFrame::isValid() check before enqueuing the
outgoing frames, so that the maximum length of the
payload field is always guaranteed, for CAN 2.0
as well as CAN FD.

[ChangeLog][CAN] Fixed potential read buffer
overflows when sending CAN frames in diverse CAN
backends which were detected by Address Sanitizer.

PeakCAN: Fix CAN 2.0 timestamp calculation

Taken from PCANBasic_enu.chm included in the PCAN-Basic library:

| Calculation of total of microseconds :
| micros + 1000 * millis + 0x100000000 * 1000 * millis_overflow

So our overflow was off by one.

CAN-commits.message:
Make pduFromStream work on big endian (again)

reinterpret_cast<char *>(&code) works on little endian, but not on big
endian, because code is an int (4 bytes value).

I fixed this bug earlier in afb7f76efafcb04e430168416d9d74113bde13bc,
but it was added back in 2c0bb738e988d84f36169e0103d051745b678479.

CAN-commits.message:
VectorCAN: Fix CAN-FD frame reading and sending

When setting the CAN device to flexible data rate mode the correct
sampling point has to be set.

When invalid CAN-FD configuration is set, respond with correct
error instead of always complain about open port.

When the bit rate switch is set for the sending frame, also set the
corresponding Vector flag.
Also set it to QCanBusFrame when receiving from Vector backend.

When an payload higher than 8 is used, the DLC has to be set to the
correct indexes.

CAN-commits.author: Stefan Steinwasser
CAN-commits.message:
VectorCAN: Set CAN-FD configuration only for uninitialized channels

The Vector plugin allows multi application access to single CAN
channels, but only the first application gets init access and
is allowed to set the configuration parameters.
On hardware devices you get an invalid access error, but the
virtual channels return an XL_ERROR and the connection fails.

[ChangeLog][CAN][Vector] Fixed XL_ERROR when try to set CAN-FD
configuration for a virtual channel which was already opened by
another application.

CAN-commits.author: Tobias Koenig
CAN-commits.message:
Fix virtual can backend usage in multithreaded environment

Protect the creation and start of the VirtualCanServer with a mutex,
so that no race conditions can occur when two QCanBusDevices with qtvirtualcan
backend are instantiated in the same process in different threads.

[ChangeLog][CAN Bus][Virtual CAN] Fixed a race condition
during creation of the VirtualCanServer when two QCanBusDevices
are instantiated in the same process in different threads

Pick-to: 6.8 6.7 6.5
Change-Id: Ic86c8ac1b83b4d7cca43124653ae095dfdaf5655
Reviewed-by: André Hartmann <aha_1980@gmx.de>
Reviewed-by: Ivan Solovev <ivan.solovev@qt.io>

CAN-commits.author: Tobias Koenig
CAN-commits.message:
Fix virtual can backend usage in multithreaded environment

Test for the current thread in VirtualCanServer::start() to prevent
that the server is started from within a different thread than the
servers one.
This situation can occur if the start() method is invoked
twice, but from different threads, and the first time the server
was created but couldn't be started successfully (e.g. because the
TCP port was already blocked by a virtual CAN server instance in
another process).

[ChangeLog][CAN Bus][Virtual CAN] Fixed a race condition
during start of the VirtualCanServer in multithreaded
environment

CAN-commits.message: Fixed bug in UI where drop target added to buffer rather than replacing

CAN-commits.author: Rob Dobson
CAN-commits.message:
Fixed a bug in BUSRQ that resulted in random crashes due to data bus conflict

The data bus direction is generally inwards - with the exception of writing to memory or responding to an IO read request (or emulated memory read request).
Sometimes after an IO read request the data bus direction can remain outwards.
When this happens and BUSRQ occurs a memory read conflict can occur.
This has now been removed by ensuring that data bus direction is inwards when a BUSRQ is requested.

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Implemented initial bitrate setting functionality, bus-off recovery and got transmit echo behaviour working.
- Recovered previously discarded functionality within drivers/net/can/dev.c thought to have been purely related to Linux network layer. However vital functionality for example bit-timing computation, are handled in this source file.
- Some further fixed to driver adv_pci.c (not yet submitted to Linux kernel).
- Introduced a set of user_* member variables in structure can_priv to replace the nla_data system, because such a complex and multi-purpose system isn't needed for this project as we only aim to implement CAN-bus functionality.
- Implmennted SJA1000 bus-off recovery timer system. Currently untested because bus-off issue disappeared after bitrate implementation.
- Got transmit echo behaviour working with flag "IFF_ECHO".

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Implementation of fixed block allocator and improved ISR handling.
- Implementation of fixed_* series of malloc and free functions for fixed block small, fixed scope use-cases to avoid malloc and free since they are not safe in ISRs. The implementation isn't robust enough for general usage, but for limited scope, well reviewed cases will be much more efficient. The implementation is also kept at such efficient levels because spinlocks are used to protect the buffers and we want to keep such locks as fast as possible.
- Added use of fixed_* series of malloc and free to structs sk_buff and can_frame in alloc_can_skb and kfree_skb.
- Removed dev_id and added net_device* to sk_buff structure.
- Fixed bug missing kfree_skb in netif_rx handler.
- Introduced logs.h variable log_enabled to control when an ISR is active to disable syslog and fprintf-stderr logs since both are not safe for interrupt handlers. Also it should be safe to declare this volatile and not require any spinlocks, because according to QNX documentation only a single CPU will ever be used for ISR handling. Quote: "On a multicore system, each interrupt is directed to one (and only one) CPU, although it doesn't matter which. How this happens is under control of the programmable interrupt controller (PIC) chip(s) on the board. When you initialize the PICs in your system's startup, you can program them to deliver the interrupts to whichever CPU you want to; on some PICs you can even get the interrupt to rotate between the CPUs each time it goes off."

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Initial Valgrind run detected issues that were then fixed.
- Running Valgrind for the first time revealed some issues. Initially Valgrind crashed with:
    vex amd64->IR: unhandled instruction bytes: 0xFA 0xBA 0x1 0x0 0x0 0x0 0x87 0x10 0x85 0xD2
    vex amd64->IR:   REX=0 REX.W=0 REX.R=0 REX.X=0 REX.B=0
    vex amd64->IR:   VEX=0 VEX.L=0 VEX.nVVVV=0x0 ESC=NONE
    vex amd64->IR:   PFX.66=0 PFX.F2=0 PFX.F3=0
    ==778262== valgrind: Unrecognised instruction at address 0x10ad5b.
    ==778262== Your program just tried to execute an instruction that Valgrind
    ==778262== did not recognise.  There are two possible reasons for this.
    ==778262== 1. Your program has a bug and erroneously jumped to a non-code
    ==778262==    location.  If you are running Memcheck and you just saw a
    ==778262==    warning about a bad jump, it's probably your program's fault.
    ==778262== 2. The instruction is legitimate but Valgrind doesn't handle it,
    ==778262==    i.e. it's Valgrind's fault.  If you think this is the case or
    ==778262==    you are not sure, please let us know and we'll try to fix it.
    ==778262== Either way, Valgrind will now raise a SIGILL signal which will
    ==778262== probably kill your program.
    Illegal instruction
- It was initially found that #if CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH_EVENT != 1 checks were missing in /src/fixed.c. Once fixed, Valgrind was crashing with "Memory fault" with core dump produced.
- Instead of ISR spinlocks, pthread mutex was implemented for CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH_EVENT and CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH build options, which was one of the reasons for the "Memory fault" in Valgrind.
- The second problem was the InterruptUnmask call in run_wait() for CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH_EVENT build option. Documentation says when using InterruptAttachEvent the kernel perform a mask and we must unmask. However there seems to be some issue either with that statement or Valgrind itself, since Valgrind is dumping on it:
    (gdb) bt
    #0  0xffff800341595030 in ?? ()
    #1  0x0000000000f32afa in InterruptUnmask (intr=<optimized out>, id=<optimized out>) at /builds/workspace/QOS222-SDP/build_x86_64/lib/c/kercover/interruptunmask.c:33
    #2  0x000000000010f088 in run_wait () at src/interrupt.c:128
    #3  0x000000000010f5c7 in main (argc=2, argv=0x7ffefff008) at src/main.c:197
- Solution was to introduce build option CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH. This is exactly like CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH_EVENT however we implement the ISR and guarantee we do not mask, so no need for unmask, thus no crash of Valgrind.

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Support for PCI type MEM blocks implemented, previously on I/O blocks were supported.
- Implmeneted changed to read*() and write*() functions to handle both I/O blocks and MEM blocks.
- Implementation of mmap_device_memory() usage for MEM type PCI blocks. Previously we only had I/O blocks with mmap_device_io(); now we handle both types.
- Going back to using "void memptr__*" instead of "uintptr_t" for device memory blocks. This is important for better alignment with Linux source-code and the introduction of MEM type PCI blocks means we need a way to store both types. The chosen method was to store in the "void memptr__*" format and then we can cast to the same size "uintptr_t" for the I/O PCI block types.
- Fixed up adv_pci.c driver and implemented pci_resource_start() and ioremap() to make the implementation better for Linux and thus better for QNX in this project.
- Implemented helper structures (bar_t and ioblock_t) and associated list management functions to handle I/O and MEM type of PCI blocks.
- Moved fixed_memory_init() to main since multiple devices are supported now, it doesn't make sense to be done in pci_enable_device().
- Implemented timer thread smooth start functionality.
- Improvements to resmgr module to allow smooth shutdown for cases when drivers fail to start.
- Minor fixes.

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Fixed incorrect handling of standard MID messages.
- Message IDs or MIDs are slightly different on QNX compared to Linux. The form of the ID depends on whether or not the driver is using extended MIDs.
  * In standard 11-bit MIDs, bits 18–28 define the MID.
  * In extended 29-bit MIDs, bits 0–28 define the MID.
- Fixed minor variable naming in cansend tool.

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Implementation of multiple IRQ support
- This commit has been done during rapid feature implementation of MSI/MSI-X support for QEmu CAN-bus interface. Thus this commit is still pending real hardware testing with known or expected issues yet to be addressed regarding MSI/MSI-X support.
- Added src/pci-capability.c to contain PCIe, MSI and MSI-X capability management functions.
- Added is_msix to pci_dev structure to track when MSI-X capability has been enabled, and pcie_cap to handle PCIe capability.
- Refactor of interrupt.c to handle multiple IRQ support
  * Now using SIGEV_PULSE event type instead of SIGEV_INTR, to allow for irq_attach array index to be passed in the sigev_code field of the event.
  * Global event variable now only used for terminate_run_wait(); graceful exit purpose only.
  * Known regression of raw Interrupt Service Routine (ISR) implementation; impacts when trying to compile with deprecated config option combination CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH=0 with CONFIG_QNX_INTERRUPT_ATTACH_EVENT=0. This combination is NOT allowed currently anyway.
  * Added code-embedded macro option MSI_DEBUG for detailed IRQ debugging; not to be released.
  * Use of cap_msi_unmask_irq_entry() and cap_msix_unmask_irq_entry() unverified with real hardware at this point.
- Implemented IRQ Management functions and structures to support multiple IRQ functionality in src/config.c and src/include/config.h
- Fixed incorrect linked-list handling; in unregister_netdev(), netif_rx(), print_driver_selection_results(), get_last_device_session(), get_last_client_session(), get_device_session(), store_resmgr(), get_resmgr(), free_all_resmgrs(), store_blocked_client(), get_blocked_client(), free_all_blocked_clients(), store_driver_selection(), probe_all_driver_selections(), remove_all_driver_selections(), store_bar(), get_bar(), store_block() and remove_block().

CAN-commits.author: Deniz Eren
CAN-commits.message:
Fix for bug https://github.com/Deniz-Eren/dev-can-linux/issues/56

No specific or hardcoded limits of 65536 or 2^16 exist in the code base.

Initial suspicion was that open/close results in a client session being created and destroyed. Client sessions have with them an RX thread per connection client (via open) to deliver the received messages. The QNX OS limit of maximum number of threads per process is known to be 32767, so we investigated whether the threads were not being cleaned up properly. This wasn't the case however, and all the threads created are detached and cleanly shutdown.

To further test this theory an experiment was done. Driver dev-can-linux was started and while monitoring the number of threads active using command "pidin -p pid" messages were sent using command "cansend -u0,tx0 -m0x1234,1,0xABCD". No increase in the number of threads noted.

Next to replicate the example code given in https://github.com/Deniz-Eren/dev-can-linux/issues/57, i.e. "void *fctThreadCan3( void *arg )", we wrote a new unit test SingleSendReceiveAfterManyOpenClose in tests/driver/io/driver-io-tests.cpp to perform the same test as test SingleSendReceive but only after opening and closing the file descriptors 100,000 times.

Exact problem described in https://github.com/Deniz-Eren/dev-can-linux/issues/56 was successfully replicated by test SingleSendReceiveAfterManyOpenClose. After running the test the command "candump -u0,rx0" no longer recieves messages from command "cansend -u0,tx0 -m0x1234,1,0xABCD".

The error message "rx_loop exit: Unable to attach to channel." was noted during the test produced from https://github.com/Deniz-Eren/dev-can-linux/blob/1bb3cfede13e847c98a309da3b5fbc415c4694ce/src/resmgr.c#L656

The problem was identified to be in rx_loop whereby the message_connect() was never being disconnected. After adding the correct disconnection the problem is shown to be fixed.

Further improvements added by making the rx_loop thread non-detached so that on close we can pthread_join() to clean-up smoother.

CAN-commits.author: Ille, Ondrej, Ing
CAN-commits.message:
1. Added explicit "tran_frame_valid" in 1 during the transmission.
   Its value is not used during the transmission, however since
   CAN Core is using metadata on outputs of TX Arbitrator, it has
   sense to keep it in 1 (to indicate validity of the data)!
2. Added FIX of addressing. Last cycle of "arb_locked" should already
   address the buffer with "metadata pointer" for following selection.
   This was a bug and it causes wrongly read timestamp in first cycle
   after unlock. Thus it could evaluate the selected frame to be valid
   for TX (timestamp elapsed), although it would not be the case! However
   in the next iteration of lookup, the timestamp is chosen properly. To
   see this bug, the Core would have to send lock command 3-4 clock cycles
   after unlock command! This is not real due to bus timing...
3. Added explicit setting of committed frame to 0 when no buffer is chosen
   combinationally. This bug in cooperation with 1 caused instable value
   on "tran_frame_valid" durintg the time buffer is locked and TX is in
   progress.

CAN-commits.author: Pavel Pisa
CAN-commits.message:
driver: fix long ago omitted byte swap in bing-endian register write.

Even on big-endian systems ioread32/iowrite32 accesses memory-mapped
register in little-endian manner to be compatible with PCI devices
so the problem of missing be in iowrite32be for ctucan_hw_write32_be
has not been found during MIPS Malta QEMU test, but it should
be corrected for case of native CTU CAN FD core mapping on big-endian
systems.

Closes #365

CAN-commits.author: Francesco Valla
CAN-commits.message:
sllin: fix 'NOHZ tick-stop error' on kernels < 5.18

The slin_send_canfr() function is called for different reasons, and in
particular both in interrupt and thread context. In the latter case,
pre-5.18 kernels complain with 'NOHZ tick-stop error: Non-RCU local
softirq work is pending', as the netif_rx() function is meant to be
called only as part of an interrupt service routine.

Fix the issue above calling netif_rx_ni() instead of netif_rx() when
not in an interrupt context.

Limit this behaviour to kernels older than 5.18, since starting with
this version netif_rx() can be called in any context and netif_rx_ni()
has been removed entirely in:

2655926aea9b: net: Remove netif_rx_any_context() and netif_rx_ni()

Signed-off-by: Francesco Valla <francesco.valla@mta.it>

CAN-commits.author: Pavel Pisa
CAN-commits.message:
sllin: guard SLSTATE_RESPONSE_SENT by timer to recover from lost in loopback.

The problem has been reported by Lin Eric from inventec.com
and solution is inspired by his patch

  Fix crash when data bytes loss occurs during Rx loopback.

Both paths (from SLSTATE_ID_SENT and SLSTATE_RESPONSE_WAIT)
to SLSTATE_RESPONSE_SENT ensure stuck protection by timer now.

The timeout error reporting is move to the worker thread
response to timeout to ensure consistency of counters etc.

Signed-off-by: Pavel Pisa <pisa@cmp.felk.cvut.cz>

CAN-commits.author: Petteri Aimonen
CAN-commits.message:
Fix security issue with PB_ENABLE_MALLOC.

The multiplication in allocate_field could potentially overflow,
leading to allocating too little memory. This could subsequently
allow an attacker to cause a write past the buffer, overwriting
other memory contents.

The attack is possible if untrusted message data is decoded using
nanopb, and the message type includes a pointer-type string or bytes
field, or a repeated numeric field. Submessage fields are not
affected.

This issue only affects systems that have been compiled with
PB_ENABLE_MALLOC enabled. Only version nanopb-0.2.7 is affected,
as prior versions do not include this functionality.

Update issue 117
Status: FixedInGit

CAN-commits.author: Petteri Aimonen
CAN-commits.message:
Fix memory leak with duplicated fields and PB_ENABLE_MALLOC.

If a required or optional field appeared twice in the message data,
pb_decode will overwrite the old data with new one. That is fine, but
with submessage fields, it didn't release the allocated subfields before
overwriting.

This bug can manifest if all of the following conditions are true:

1. There is a message with a "optional" or "required" submessage field
   that has type:FT_POINTER.

2. The submessage contains atleast one field with type:FT_POINTER.

3. The message data to be decoded has the submessage field twice in it.

CAN-commits.author: Petteri Aimonen
CAN-commits.message:
Fix missing warning with large bytes fields (issue #220)

Need to generate compile time check if the bytes field + size field
might exceed 255 bytes. Also eliminated spurious checks generated
for some callback fields.

CAN-commits.author: Petteri Aimonen
CAN-commits.message:
Fix multiple oneofs in same message (issue #229)

Previously the field iterator logic didn't know whether two
oneof fields were part of the same union, or separate. This
caused wrong pointers to be calculated if multiple oneofs were
inside a single message.

This commit fixes this by using dataoffset of PB_SIZE_MAX to
indicate union fields after the first field.

Theoretically PB_SIZE_MAX is also a valid value for data offset,
which could cause errors. Adding a compile-time assert for this
is somewhat difficult. However I consider it extremely unlikely
that there is any platform that could trigger this situation, as
it would require 255 bytes of extra data/padding between two protobuf
oneof fields. On 64-bit architectures the worst case is 16 bytes,
and even esoteric platforms only align to 64 bytes or so. Manual
modification of the generated .pb.h file could trigger this, but
even then it would require pretty bad luck to happen.

[binding]Protect signal dedicated write with LOA

Use the same LOA than the general purpose verb write to write using a signal verb.
This fix a security hole where we could possibly write any signal on a CANbus without
any authentication.

Fix link dependency issue for plugins

the link options, just set it implicitly in the pc file.

CAN-commits.author: Louis-Baptiste Sobolewski
CAN-commits.message:
Fix error message for duplicate msg_def ID

Message definition name field seems to always be empty, so let's use
plugin name instead. Also specify which ID is duplicated in an hex
format so the user can find the problem more easily in their JSON
signal description files.

CAN-commits.author: Louis-Baptiste Sobolewski
CAN-commits.message:
Fix diagnostic message frequency & enforce minimum freq

Old code was using the first diagnostic message's frequency for all
diagnostic messages. In the case of the vcar plugin, that means all
messages were set at 5Hz, using 6.5KBps of CAN bus bandwidth. Fixing
this more than halved bandwidth usage.

A frequency of 0Hz has kind of an undefined behavior, sometimes
saturating the bus, sometimes not behaving strangelly. A minimum
frequency of 0.05Hz (20 minutes period) is enforced for messages
with a specified frequency of 0Hz or no specified frequency.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Add parent pointer to CAN mesage callback data

Added parent class context to CAN message callbacks.
This helps the recipient of a callback know what object the callback was destined for.
Fixed network manager timestamp not being updated.
Fix evicting CF address was always evicting without verifying that the address of the claim matched the table

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[TP]: Fix issues with CM TP Tx session spanning multiple CTS/RTS cycles

There was a bug in CM TP Tx sessions where if the packet was broken up into multple CTS/RTS chunks, the stack would send repeated data and abort.
These issues should now be resolved.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fixed an issue with the socket CAN interface not processing Tx messages at full speed

There was an issue when transmitting out of the CAN message transmit queue where we would only pull the first item out of the queue every iteration.
This was causing us to under-utilize the bus, and take longer to send TP messages than needed.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[TP]: Fix TP wouldn't send exactly 1785 bytes

There was an off-by-one error when comparing the maximum protocol payload for TP to the transmit size.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[ETP]: Fix ETP protocol would accept a message destined for global, when it can actually only handle destination specific messages

This could have cause a crash when doing a TP BAM transmit

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fixed a truncation when constructing a CAN ID with a broadcast PGN

This would cause incorrect PGNs to be reported in a BAM message

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[TP]: Fixed several issues with transmitting a BAM session

I found that transmitting a BAM session was missing several components while working on the DM1 and DM2 messages.
In particular, sending the actual BAM itself was missing, the frame timing for BAM was missing, and I was using some bad assumptions in the code from CM.
This commit allows BAM sessions to actually send and complete.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[DP] Added support for ISO 11783 Product Identification requests

Now if you request PGN 0xFC8D, the stack will send the appropriate response, which contains the product ID code, brand, and model information.
Also fixed erroneous DM2 ACK when all we really need to do is send the DM2 on request

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fix a small memory leak in the socket CAN layer

When exiting, we now clean up the socket CAN layer better so that we delete any allocated frame handlers and stop relying on a user to do it.
Previously this would leak about 232 bytes per CAN channel right at exit time.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fix a segfault that could happen on exit

The way we were cleaning up the frame handlers before the refactor of CAN Hardware Interface is no longer needed since they are managed outside that class.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message: [Core]: Fix unneeded includes in CAN Hardware Interface causing a linux dependency even when not using socket CAN

CAN-commits.author: GwnDaan
CAN-commits.message:
[VT] Fix pool size with 8 bytes left in last message not correctly uploading

Also added missing loggings for ETP session aborts

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fix getting the CAN Stack logger would always return nullptr

This would cause segfaults for custom loggers, but should now work OK.
Tested with std::cout logger on issue #70

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[FP]: Add internal control function valid check before accepting fast packet transmit

This should fix transmits returning true when address claiming is incomplete.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message: [TP]: Fix a nasty off-by-one error when decoding TP.CM packets

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[#90]: Add Windows PEAK PCAN Support

Adds the windows PCAN libraries from the PCAN API.
Adds a new hardware plugin for PCAN on Windows. (The linux one is different and I will need to add it seperately).
Added readme for 3rd party drivers where we can put any important info related to them.
Made all examples support Windows if compiled with -DCAN_DRIVER=WindowsPCANBasic.
Fixed attempting to compile unit tests if BUILD_TESTING is enabled but socket CAN is not present.
Added a bunch of crazy CMake to detect the target architecture when compiling with MSVC because that functionality is totally broken in CMAKE. See https://gitlab.kitware.com/cmake/cmake/-/issues/15170

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[#121]: Fix ETP Rx DPO not matching CTS

CAN Stack would complain that the ETP client DPO didn't match our CTS, but in reality we just weren't saving the expected packet count at the end of a session.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[#121]: Fix ETP Rx protocol off-by-1 and using the wrong counter for overall data indexing

This would cause data to be overwritten in the Rx packet when the packer number rolled over.

CAN-commits.message:

Instead of reading object as u64 it should've been u16

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fix the sonar blocker items

Fixed issue in TP similar to the one I fixed in #141
Fixed a check where the scanner was worried about class slicing (but no slicing was probably happening?)
Add a condition to the can thread wait. We really just want it to always wake up, as there are tons of things that trigger that thread but guidelines say we should have some condition.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Core]: Fix a crash that can occur if a hardware channel is nullptr

This fixes a crash that might manifest if your CAN hardware is invalid and you call `Start` on the hardware interface.

CAN-commits.message:

This is a temporary fix to pass the PR CI from failing, and allows us to implement this test at a later stage

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[#245]: Moved NMEA2k fast packet protocol instance to the network manager

Moved the fast packet protocol instance into the network manager to prevent it from getting optimized out when linking as a static library.
Added a getter to the network manager to get the protocol instance.
Fixed one session variable not being initialized at construction (though this probably was not causing issues).
Updated the FP example to use the new protocol instance.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[DDOP]: Fixed length and object reference issues in DDOP deserializer

Fixed DDOP device object length when deserializing from a TC version 3
or lower pool.
Fixed not adding device element object's child objects when
deserializing.
Fixed a bug when determining a DVP object's scale causing it to always
be zero.
Added a function to get DDOP objects by index, so that a TC server
can access every object without having to search all 65535 IDs.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[DP]: Diagnostic Protocol tests and various enhancements

Added numerous DP unit tests.
Fixed DP example not saving the periodic event dispatcher.
Added example use of ECUID Type.
Added a way to get the broadcast state and init state of the diagnostic
protocol.
Added processing of the suspend type for DM13 to allow for custom
broadcast suspension times.
Added support for PGN requests for the DM1 PGN.
Fixed issues with ECU ID sending too many fields when operating in
J1939 mode.
Enhanced message queuing for requests for ECU and software ID.
Fixed busload unit test which was affected by adding DP tests.
Slightly increased the timeout on language command timestamp unit test.
Fixed an intermittent issue with TC unit tests that came from changing
to shared ptr for control functions due to the tests claiming the same
address with no network manager updates between destroying a partner
and claiming a new one.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[FP]: Fixed fast packet session packet count issues

Fixed sending or receiving one extra packet when the total data count
in a FP session was exactly on a frame boundary.
Fixed crash with some FP sessions where setting multipacket payloads
would overrun the bounds of the message data vector.
Clarified a log message.

(cherry picked from commit 8fd14ac6253d02eb96f9385157943aff848be36e)

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[#310]: Fix incorrect relocation of partner CFs with very similar NAME filters

Fixed situations where consecutive address claims by partners that
were very similar based on NAME filters would cause an already valid
partner to be overwritten with a different partner's address data.
Also, locked TC example to use the primary TC.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[ETP]: Fixed an issue where receiving some ETP sessions could cause a crash

Fixed a boundary check when receiving an ETP session when reconstructing
the message payload in the final frame of the session.

CAN-commits.author: Adrian Del Grosso
CAN-commits.message:
[Meta]: Updated some outdated README info

Added missing supported CAN plugins to the list.
Fixed some outdated compilation commands.
Added instructions to acquire Git in addition to CMake, especially for Windows.
Added instructions for how to integrate the library with FetchContent.
Clarified that we don't officially provide precompiled versions of the library.

CAN-commits.author: woodward1
CAN-commits.message:
fixed corrupted can id bug

There was an error in the bit arithmatic for the can id.

Basically, if the 15th bit of the id was set, then the upper 16bits were 1 less than they should be.
e.g. 0x0001(8-F)XXX -> 0x0000(8-F)XXX
e.g. 0x0000(8-F)XXX -> 0xFFFF(8-F)XXX

The offending operation is (tbufdata[MCP_EID8]<<8). This promotes an unsigned char to a signed int, which results in the corrupted ids. The fix is to cast it to an unsigned int. Note that int's are 16 bit on avr.

CAN-commits.author: Ingo Peukes
CAN-commits.message:
Bugfix: When receiving a frame with remote request bit set
not clearing m_nRtr until next data frame without request bit is
received. This lead to sending out all frames in between with
request bit set aswell. Fixed by extending sendMsgBuf to
INT8U sendMsgBuf(INT32U id, INT8U ext, INT8U rtr, INT8U len, INT8U *buf)
and setMsg to
INT8U setMsg(INT32U id, INT8U ext, INT8U len, INT8U rtr, INT8U *pData)
giving the possibillity to specify if request bit is set or not when
sending a message.

Feature: New function INT8U MCP_CAN::isRemoteRequest(void) added
to make it possible to check if the remote request bit was set on
the last received message.

CAN-commits.author: Laurent De Coninck
CAN-commits.message:
fix the access of the bank account of one user

There are 3 ways to access this tab :
    1. If the module holiday is enabled
    2. If the module holidays is enabled
    3. If the module expense report is enabled

More over that, the application checks if the user can access the bank
account of the selected user. The application does that twice (logical
^^), first to know if the tab has to be displayed or not. Second time,
when you arrive on the page /user/bank.php to know if you have access
(eg. if you type the url directly).

In this second check, the check of the expense report module was missing
(added by this PR). This caused the following issue: the tab was visible
but when the user clicked on itn, he received an error as he cannot
access the page.

CAN-commits.author: zuiko
CAN-commits.message:
Update functions.lib.php

Fix #15820
function price2num
add underscore and - in the pattern in instruction 
$amount = preg_replace('/[a-zA-Z\/\\\*\(\)\<\>]/', '', $amount);
as this:
$amount = preg_replace('/[a-zA-Z\/\\\*\(\)\<\>\_\-]/', '', $amount);
in order to cover some constantes cases as 20% (TX_NORMAL) or 10% (TX_REDUIT) for example where underscore or - can be used.

I don't know if other characters have to be added to this pattern.

CAN-commits.author: antonin_tdj
CAN-commits.message:
Fix Bug replenish + Auto Filter

# Fix Replenish Calculation Bug + Auto Filter

## Environment
* Version: 13
* URL(s): product/stock/replenish.php

## Configuration 
MultiCompany needed with Stock Sharing ON, 2 entities and 1 warehouse per entity

**Entity A**
* Options: don't share stocks with other entities
* Warehouse : only 1 (WAR_A)
* Stock : 1 product (PROD) Qty : 4

**Entity B :**
* Options: don't share stocks with other entities
* Warehouse : only 1 (WAR_B)
* Stock : 1 product --the same-- (PROD) Qty : 17

**Product :**
* Desired Stock : 20
* Alert : 10

**WAR_A :**
* For the product
* Desired Stock : 16
* Alert : 6
 
## Fixed behavior :
* Entity A -> Replenish
* If WAR_A selected should show the product and fill with 12 the qty to order. Physical Stock (All) and Physical Stock (this 
warehouse) should be 4.

* If no Warehouse selected show the product and fill with 12 (because only one warehouse seen by this entity) the qty to order. Physical Stock (All) should be 4.

## Actual behavior :
* Entity A -> Replenish

* The product isn't showed.

* If I intentionally incrementes the Desired Stock value. The product will be shown with the good filter (Warehouse if desired stock has been incremented on the combination ProductDesired <-> Warehouse). The qty for the order are correct and the physical stock shown is correct.

## Conclusion : 
* 1 bug and 1 improvment

**BUG** : The value of the stock taken to whether or not show the product line is wrong. It is considering the stock in warehouses not shared with the entity.

**IMPROVMENT** : If only one Warehouse, take automatically the desired and alert values for this warehouse and not the general ones.

`null`. Instead we should do this
`$hookmanager->resArray['classname']`.

CAN-commits.author: Indelog
CAN-commits.message:
Fix append module suffix on src_object_type when create ecm file

Files added to `llx_ecm_files` for externals modules never be removed on
object deletion.

When `CommonObject::deleteEcmFiles()` is called with `mode=1`, it  use
this sql filter to find the file related to the object which is removed
:

```
$sql .= " WHERE fk_object IN (SELECT rowid FROM ".MAIN_DB_PREFIX."ecm_files WHERE src_object_type = '".$this->db->escape($this->table_element.(empty($this->module) ? '' : '@'.$this->module))."' AND src_object_id = ".((int) $this->id).")";
```

We see it append `'@'.$this->module` to `$this->table_element` but when
file is add to the `llx_ecm_files` by
`CommonObject::commonGenerateDocument()` , it added whiteout the
`'@'.$this->module` suffix. So the file is never remove from
`llx_ecm_files` when object is deleted.

This fix it by appending module suffix on `src_object_type` if object
has `module` property when add document to the `llx_ecm_files`.

CAN-commits.author: Manoel Vilela
CAN-commits.message:
Make GNU std compliant of seq + add tests

Seq is not POSIX, so I follwing the implementation by GNU
Now we can choose the step with same syntax:

seq [start] [step] <end>

SYNOPSIS
       seq [OPTION]... LAST
       seq [OPTION]... FIRST LAST
       seq [OPTION]... FIRST INCREMENT LAST

This flags was implemented:
	-w 	width fixed with leading zeros
	-f	format custom like %.2f, for float nums
	-s	separator string for each element

Change-Id: Id2bd3612f5e8931575261b74b3b6a2da5d8fbfd4
Signed-off-by: Manoel Vilela <manoel_vilela@engineer.com>

CAN-commits.author: Ryan O'Leary
CAN-commits.message:
Fix ps to be stable with terminated processes

Procfs is very alive. Subdirectories can be added and removed at
anytime. `os.Walk`ing over `/proc` and expecting a file to exist on a
subsequent syscall is a race condition waiting to happen.

The solution is to implement a simpler version of `os.Walk` which simply
walks over a single directory. Additionally, "file does not exist"
errors are ignored.

I tested this issue by killing many processes per second:

	while true; do /bin/true; done

In another terminal, run:

	for i in {1..1000}; do ./ps > /dev/null; done

No longer will you see fatal error messages and SIGSEVs.

Fixes #28

Signed-off-by: Ryan O'Leary <ryanoleary@google.com>

CAN-commits.author: Ronald G. Minnich
CAN-commits.message:
usage: fix up usage so we can keep using flag.Usage

In some cases we had been writing our own usage function,
which leads to awkward looking output. It turns out that
if one wants more information than just os.Args[0], one
can set os.Args[0] before calling flag.Usage.

This change uses a function literal to create closure
to be assigned to flag.Usage such that we can set os.Args[0]
and get more natural looking output, e.g.

date -z
flag provided but not defined: -z
Usage of date [-u] [+format] | date [-u] [MMDDhhmm[CC]YY[.ss]]:
  -u    Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)

This will also allow us to better use the busybox mode. It provides
its own usage function but this design will let us provide our additional
text while still using the busybox functtion too.

Signed-off-by: Ronald G. Minnich <rminnich@gmail.com>

CAN-commits.author: Ronald G. Minnich
CAN-commits.message:
add stty command

You can do things like
stty Raw

Default is to just print stuff out.

You can say
stty Save
and it will dump JSON. The intent is that at some point (once we need it) we can
say
stty Restore < file.json

and it get restored, or even
stty Save | sed command | stty Restore

and you can have a filter that modifies stty settings.

You can also do this:

stty Save > push.json
stty Raw

do stuff

stty Restore < push.json

i.e. stty is more unix-like than it's been.

Also, the stty struct in termios.go is intended to have enough struct members to cover a superset of uses, so it
may nbot fit all cases. I.e. there might be a variable in there that would have no meaning on OSX.

This is all a bit crude but was sufficient to let me debug the elvish problem on serial consoles. As was expected,
elvish is not handling the cols being 0.
So
stty Col 80
fixed elvish on serial console.

We really need to just fix elvish so that if it sees 0 as col it handles it. If it is so dependent on
stty settings it needs to have some sanity built in.

Changes welcome, I realize this is kind of rough.

Just keep in mind, termios.go is supposed to be sort of OS-agnostic, with nasty bits in termios_os.go. Also, lest anyone
forget, this should be able to work on systems like plan 9 and harvey, in which text is the control, not weird
bits of binary crap.

So make sure that setOpt is always implemented with []string, ok? Not ints or magic bits.

Signed-off-by: Ronald G. Minnich <rminnich@gmail.com>

CAN-commits.message:
ping: fix fd exhaustion

So far "defer" was used in a loop, which keeps fds open till the program
terminates or we run out of fds.

You can watch fd creation without giving them up like this:
watch -n1 sudo ls /proc/`pidof ping`/fd

CAN-commits.author: Tobias Fleig
CAN-commits.message:
Fix switch_root

This fixes/changes a number of things in switch_root:
- Changed overall order to what seems to be the universally-agreed-upon way to do switch_root:
  1. Move the special mounts (/proc, /sys, ...)
  2. Keep a file descriptor for /
  3. Move the root mount
  4. Chroot to .
  5. Delete old root with file descriptor
  6. Exec init
- Use real exec (syscall), we were not able to get the NEWPID fork magic
  to work reliably. Also the old exec code used flags that are mutably
  exclusive?!
- Rewrote the deletion code to be based on file descriptors
- Handle symlinks in deletion code (would previously crash)
- Also migrate /run, if found
- Root mount move no longer hardcodes 'ext4' fs type, so should work on
  all root fs now.

Given the fact that mutually exclusive flags were used, I have some
suspicion the code never ran in this state. With this version, we
successfully switch_rooted into a vanilla CentOS, and systemd started up
just fine.

We copy-pasted two snippets from the go-runtime (we put them in utils.go).
One of them is private in the runtime, and the other one is not
available in any stable version yet. Both can obviously be removed as
soon as the runtime equivalents become available.

CAN-commits.author: Ronald G. Minnich
CAN-commits.message:
ACPI package

This package supports reading and writing of ACPI tables.

There are three models of tables supported:
Raw, tables which just consist of a []byte
Generic, tables which consist of the standard Header and []byte

The third type contains very specific structures; one example
you can see is in sdt.go, where we read in the header, and
also the pointers.

All of the tables implement the Tabler interface, which allows
programs to query values of standard header items such as
signature, length, revision, and so on; as well as
Marshal them out.

It is easy to convert a Raw to a Generic and a Generic to
a more refined table. The latter requires a table-specific
unmarshaler, however.

You can see in types.go that we define a set of standard
scalar types, and use those types in fns.go. For example, there is
a signature type which is just a string. You can use these
types to create table schemas.

I experimented with using structure member tags and this
other model of purpose-made types. The latter proved more
convenient. You can see in ibft.go how they are used.

Since we don't care about most tables, we don't implement
them; we just use Raw.

The ibft.go tables were created directly from the ACPI
spec, via scripts; should we wish to implement more tables,
at some point we should just write a go program to slurp in the
spec and generate structs and constants. It's just too painful
to do it any other way.

One other point. If you want to generate a new table for, e.g.,
kexec, it's pretty certain you'll have to put the [XR]SDT at
the address pointed to by the RSDP, as the RSDP is usually
in write-protected (by the PCH!) RAM. The bits that protect
that RAM are not resettable save by a power-on/reset cycle.
Writes to that area are transparently discarded; see all the
snarky notes in the source about that.
If you are wondering whyMarshalAll is implemented as it is,
now you know: [XR]SDT can't move.

I'm open to suggestions on ways to do this better, moving forward,
but be aware that for now, this works to let us add tables using
our kexec multiboot support in u-root. Be aware that with ACPI,
barely good enough is usually all you can expect. Just see the
ACPICA code some time :-)

This commit also includes a hack to fix the dmesg test because
I can't get it to work any other way.

Signed-off-by: Ronald G. Minnich <rminnich@gmail.com>

CAN-commits.author: Simran Singh
CAN-commits.message:
securelaunch: helpers: Add mountCache to speed up boot

Currently we are using sluinit to do things in the following sequence:
1. get tpm handle
2. get policy (mount all devices until we find policy file)
3. collect evidence (DMI, Files, Storage, CPUID) (all collectors mount devices except DMI collector)
4. measure target kernel & initrd (mount device twice once for kernel and once for initrd)
5. dump eventlogs to disk (mount device for target location of dump)
6. Launcher for boot.(mount device for getting kernel and initrd files)

Notice how many times we are mounting and unmounting disks...
Now lets take the case when the user enters same disk for all these (e.g sda2).
That would mean in one sluinit sequence, we will mount and unmount sda2 about 9 times

Sigh... That really is inefficient consider a single mount attempts to match different kinds of
filesystems(ext3, ext4, xfs) before finally mounting....a single mount typically can take around 15-20 secs.

My proposal to fix this inefficiency is to have a mount cache.
first time we mount a device, keep the device mounted and store the mountPath in a map(cache).
that way if a device is already mounted...we can use the map to lookup for a given device and get the mountPath.
At the last step of sluinit before kexecing, we go over the map and unmount all keys left in the map.

We would be needing a lock for cache since maps in go are not concurrent safe.

This also makes GetMountedFilePath function simpler since we no longer need to return mountPath.

Note that mount flags make things slightly complicated. if a device is in cache with read flag
and we want to write to the same device, we would need to unmount the device, delete the map entry
and mount the same device again with write flags. Our goal should be to minimize number of remounts of
same device.

Signed-off-by: Simran Singh <simran.p.singh@oracle.com>

CAN-commits.author: Chris Koch
CAN-commits.message:
trampoline: find info,entry,magic location using funcPC

The crux of the problem is that we're trying to find these symbols'
location in order to insert some bytes at each. Until now, we've done
this by putting some strings before the symbol, and finding the string
in the trampoline, and then replacing the bytes in the function _after_
assuming a Go compiler's alignment of 16 bytes.

Go 1.15's
https://github.com/golang/go/commit/30f8074e3510da8c39f879cfdbde600eb876a79e
changes the default alignment of functions from 16 to 32 bytes.

We could decide to use 16 bytes for <= Go 1.14 and 32 bytes for >= Go
1.15. Instead, each symbol is treated like a function so we can use funcPC
to find their location. This fix works in Go 1.13, 1.14, as well as 1.15
without keying off an internal Go compiler alignment value.

Fixes #1803

Signed-off-by: Chris Koch <chrisko@google.com>

CAN-commits.author: Ronald G. Minnich
CAN-commits.message:
pkg/cpio, cmds/core/cpio: Allow reading from pipes

Currently, the cpio package can not read from pipes. This violates
a fundamental property of both cpio and Unix in general.

The fix might seem to be allowing creation of Readers from an os.File.
We could then see if the File in question implements Reader or
ReaderAt: if ok, rat := f.(ReaderAt) ...
and handle each case, transparent to the caller.

The problem is that some Go os.File types, such as Pipes,
advertise themselves as implementing ReaderAt but in fact do not
do so.

e.g.
	r, _, _ := os.Pipe()
	var b [2]byte
	var _ io.ReaderAt = r
	_, err := r.ReadAt(b[:], 0)
	fmt.Printf("%v", err)

will fail, since whatever Go may think, Linux pipes do not allow a
seek, even when the offset is not changing. So the test
above will not work.

The Go runtime needs to be fixed, so that it does not claim
pipes implement io.ReaderAt, but it's going to be a long
time before such a change propagates everywhere. The cpio package
must accomodate this error. Further, there will almost
certainly be other future types which make this mistake.

Provide a NewFileReader function, which accepts *os.File
and returns a Reader. The function performs a simple test,
io.Seek(0,0), and, if that works, just creates a Reader
using the File's ReadAt.

If that seek fails, the function wraps the file in a
discardreader.

It is best to use a ReadAt when possible to avoid having
to read and discard data to implement seek.

cpio can now use stdin from a pipe.

Signed-off-by: Ronald G. Minnich <rminnich@gmail.com>

CAN-commits.message:
Fix zipslips for cpio, tar and zip

Fixes the following CVEs:

* CVE-2020-7669
* CVE-2020-7666
* CVE-2020-7665

A zipslip is when a archive contains a path which escapes the extract
directory. This can be done with absolute paths `/` or with parent
directories `..`. It is a security problem.

These commands will no longer extract those directories and instead
print a warning.

CAN-commits.author: Ronald G. Minnich
CAN-commits.message:
pkg/mount: do not MkdirAll the mountpoint by default

Remove the code that always does a MkdirAll in mount.Mount.

Making the mountpoint by default is nonstandard behavior.
It was introduced in 74c94c.
It must have been useful, I assume, else we would not have done it?

This code can have all kinds of confusing consequences, e.g.
imagine a script that does this:
mount /dev/sda1 /mnnt
ls -l /dev/mnt

/mnnt will be created, but it's not what the caller intended by
any means!

Further, mount.Mount does not allow callers to set the mode to other than
666.

At the same time, the behavior can be useful, so change
mount.Mount as follows:
func Mount(dev, path, fsType, data string, flags uintptr, opts ...func() error)

Then, callers wishing to do a few things ahead of time can do so:
mount.Mount("none", dst, fstype, "", 0, func() error {return os.Mount(dst, 0o644)})

Note that the fixed default mode is no longer the case: callers can
set the mode as needed.

This is a breaking change, possibly, for users of this package :-(
But current behavior is not good, so this change may be worth the pain.

Includes an extra test for the opts.

Signed-off-by: Ronald G. Minnich <rminnich@gmail.com>

CAN-commits.author: Avi Brender
CAN-commits.message:
bzimage: Fix broken decompression.

The (poorly documented) compressed kernel payload is actually
the compressed payload + 4 bytes containing the uncompressed size ([1]
[2]). The code in bzimage.go assumed that these 4 trailing bytes were
part of the compressed payload, which lead to (1) decompression always
returning an error (see #2300) (2) commenting out of code to check
stderr of the decompressor (3) inclusion of the "String of unknown
meaning" aka initRAMFStag in the code.

This code (1) adds in the proper parsing of the trailing 4 bytes (2)
rewrites the code used when swapping the compressed kernel with a
smaller one (3) adds test coverage to catch cases that previously would
have failed.

Fixes #2300.

[1] https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/arch/x86/boot/compressed/mkpiggy.c#L40-L47
[2] https://github.com/torvalds/linux/blob/master/arch/x86/boot/compressed/Makefile#L18

Signed-off-by: Avi Brender <abrender@google.com>

CAN-commits.author: Avi Brender
CAN-commits.message:
Fix bzImage decompression support.

* Add a `decompressor` interface which is an abstraction for a function that can decompress compressed bytes.
* Add decompressor that supports executing a command which reads compressed bytes via STDIN and writing uncompressed bytes via STDOUT
* Add decompressors for gzip lzma lz4 and bzip2 formats using native Go packages. This saves the overhead of forking a new process to decompress.
* Add verification that the compressed payload contains an ELF.
* Add a test image for every compressed format available.

Signed-off-by: Avi Brender <abrender@google.com>

CAN-commits.author: Ronald G. Minnich
CAN-commits.message:
pkg/efivarfs: correctly fix tmpdir removal

d6bd58d6a4e8c1f00b1fa996b8d2876acfaf9c0f added a skipifnotroot
to avoid a tmpdir removal problem.

This was not the correct fix. The problem was that a file, once
made immutable, has to be made mutable, or it can not be removed.

In the test, restore a file to mutability before ending the test.

The test can now be run as any user.

CAN-commits.author: Conrad Parker
CAN-commits.message:
efivarfs: Fix fs_test.go to end with mutable file

f12209a invoked restore to fix a tmpdir removal problem. However,
restore returns the file to an immutable state, not a mutable one. As
such, the file was left in an immutable (and hence unremovable) state at
the end of the test.

The previous code was likely passing tests because the erroneous code
was being skipped when the immutable flag couldn't be set on the test
file. I've tested my changes as root and confirmed that they work and do
not skip any parts of this test.

The following changes are made to fs_test.go:

* Remove the restore == nil check, since makeMutable only returns nil
  restore on error
* To properly test makeMutable:
  * Set the file's immutable bit before calling makeMutable
  * Observe that the file's immutable bit is now unset
  * End the test without calling restore to ensure that the file can be
    cleaned up

Signed-off-by: Conrad Parker <conradparker@google.com>
